text: Consider the following information: (2024) | | Archaeological Site | State | Description | |----|-----------------------|-------------|-------------------| | 1 | Chandraketugarh | Odisha | Trading Port Town | | 2 | Inamgaon | Maharashtra | Chalcolithic site | | 3 | Mangadu | Kerala | Megalithic site | | 4 | Salihundam | Andhra | Rock-cut | In which of the above rows is the given information correctly matched? -
explanation: Pair 1 is not correctly matched: Chandraketugarh is situated in West Bengal. It is likely a prominent trading center due to its strategic location near river routes connecting the region with other parts of India and potentially Southeast Asia. Pair 2 is correctly matched: Inamgaon, located in the Pune district of Maharashtra, India, is a significant archaeological site that provides valuable insights into the Deccan Chalcolithic (Copper Age) culture. Thus, pair 2 is correctly matched. Pair 3 is correctly matched: Mangadu, a newly discovered prehistoric site in Kerala, features a substantial number of megaliths dating from approximately 1000 B.C. to 100 B.C. This makes it a noteworthy site for megalithic studies. Pair 4 is not correctly matched: Salihundam, situated in the Srikakulam district of Andhra Pradesh, gained prominence through archaeological excavations revealing an ancient Buddhist settlement. However, it is not known for its rock-cut shrines.
subject: history_ancient

text: Which one of the following ancient towns is well-known for its elaborate system of water harvesting and management by building a series of dams and channelizing water into connected reservoirs? (2021) -
explanation: Option (a) is correct: The city of Dholavira was an ancient town of the Indus Valley Civilization (IVC). It is well-known for its elaborate system of water harvesting and management by building a series of dams and channelizing water into connected reservoirs . Planners in the ancient city of Dholavira had conceptualised an amazing system of drains, dams, and tanks to manage water. To conserve every drop of water, they carefully considered everything. Unlike other Harappan antecedent towns, unacademy.com | Download the Unacademy app Give your feedback here: Link <!-- image --> Dholavira was strategically located on the island of Khadir to harness various mineral and raw material sources (copper, shell, agatecarnelian, steatite, lead, banded limestone, and others) and to facilitate internal and external trade to the Magan (modern Oman peninsula) and Mesopotamian regions. <!-- image -->

text: Which one of the following is not a Harappan site? (2019) -
explanation: The history of India begins with the birth of the Indus Valley Civilization which flourished around 2,500 BC, in the western part of South Asia, in contemporary Pakistan and Western India. The first city to be unearthed was Harappa and hence Indus Valley Civilization, also known as Harappan Civilization. The Indus Valley was home to the largest of the four ancient urban civilizations of Egypt, Mesopotamia, India, and China. Since it belongs to the Bronze/ Chalcolithic age, the Indus Valley Civilization is also known as the Bronze Age Civilization. Option (c) is correct: Sohgaura is not a Harappan Site. It is a village on the banks of the Rapti River, about 20 km south-east of Gorakhpur, in the Gorakhpur District, Uttar Pradesh, India. It is known for Indian copper plate inscriptions written in Prakrit in the Brahmi script. <!-- image --> Bactria-Margiana Complex Archaeolog√≠cal Mundigak Culture (Helmand) Kulli Culture Sotka Koh Sutkagen Dor Shortugai Indus Valley Civilisation -Mature Phase- <!-- image --> ## Additional Information: - y Kot Diji: It was a pre-Harappan site located on the left bank of River Sindh. - y Chanhudaro: It is situated 130 kms south of Mohenjo-Daro in Sindh and is the only site without a fortified citadel. - y Desalpur: It is a mature Harappan site situated near Gunthali in Nakhatrana Taluka of the Kutch district, famous for disproportionately large fortifications.

text: During this period, cotton was used for manufacturing textiles in India. Which of the statements given above is/are correct? -
options: Neither 1 nor 2 unacademy.com | Download the Unacademy app Give your feedback here: Link 1 ## Prehistoric Period and Indus Valley Civilisation-Explanation
explanation: Statement 1 is correct: The Ramayana has mention of chariots covered with leather. The Kshatriyas used to go for combat on the chariots that were equipped with asi (swords), hanas (arrows), and ilhianus (bows). Rigvedic Aryans used the coat of mail and helmet in warfare, whereas the people of the Indus Valley Civilization did not leave any evidence of using them. Statement 2 is not correct: The metals which were used by Indo-Aryans in the time of the Rigveda were gold and copper or bronze, but in the times of Yajurveda and Atharvaveda, these metals were supplemented by silver and iron. Among the people of the Indus Valley, silver was more common than gold. The utensils and the vessels were sometimes made out of stone which was a relic of the Neolithic Ageas as well as copper and bronze. However, there has been no evidence of Iron. Statement 3 is correct: The Rig Veda mentions horse-drawn chariots with spoked wheels. However, there is very little archaeological evidence of horses during the Harappan era and none earlier. Elimination Technique: During IVC people were aware of bronze, the famous Lost Wax Technique was used for Bronze Casting. So, we can eliminate the option B and D.

text: Upanishads were composed earlier than the Puranas. Which of the statements given above is/are correct? -
explanation: Option (c) is correct Madhyama-vyayoga is a Sanskrit play attributed to Bhasa who was a famous Sanskrit poet. The play revolves around the characters from the Mahabharata, focusing on an episode involving Bhima and his son Ghatotkacha. Option (a) is not correct: Kavyalankara is attributed to the poet and literary theorist Bhamaha. It is a treatise on poetics and aesthetics, discussing various aspects of literary ornamentation and style. Option (b) is not correct: Natyashastra attributed to the sage Bharata Muni, is a comprehensive treatise on performing arts, including drama, dance, and music. It provides guidelines for actors, playwrights, and directors. Option (d) is not correct: Mahabhashya important work attributed to the grammarian Patanjali. It is a commentary on the grammar rules of Panini's Ashtadhyayi and has had a significant influence on Sanskrit linguistics.

explanation: Dhanyakataka, also known as Amaravati, was an important Buddhist centre that flourished under the Mahasanghika sect. It was situated in present-day Guntur district of the Indian state of Andhra Pradesh. Dhanyakataka was renowned for its Buddhist stupas and monastic complexes. It played a significant role in the spread of Buddhism in ancient South India and was a major centre for Buddhist learning and pilgrimage. The site is known for its ancient ruins and Buddhist sculptures, including the famous Amaravati Stupa. These archaeological remains provide insights into the rich Buddhist heritage that thrived in the region centuries ago.

explanation: Option (b) is correct: Sthanakvasi is a sect of Svetambara Jainism founded by a merchant named Lavaji in 1653 AD. It believes that idol worship is not essential in the path of soul purification and attainment of Nirvana or Moksha. The sect is essentially a reformation of the one founded on teachings of Lonka, a fifteenth-century Jain reformer. Jainism is an ancient religion that follows the philosophy of liberation and also a path to spiritual purity and enlightenment through disciplined nonviolence to all living creatures. Jainism came into prominence in 6 th century B.C. when Lord Mahavira propagated the religion. There were 24 great teachers, the last of whom was Lord Mahavira. Jain order has been divided into two major sects: Digambar and Svetambara. <!-- image -->

text: Lord Buddha's image is sometimes shown with the hand gesture called 'Bhumisparsha Mudra'. It symbolises: (2012) -
options: Buddha's calling of the Earth to watch over Mara and to prevent Mara from disturbing his meditation. -

Buddha's reminder to his followers that they all arise from the Earth and finally dissolve into the Earth, and thus this life is transitory. -
Both the statements (a) and (b) are correct in this context
explanation: Option (b) is correct: Bhumisparsha means touching the earth. It is most commonly known as the 'earth witness' mudra. This mudra involves all the five fingers of the right hand extended to touch the ground. This posture of mudra symbolises the pose of Buddha at the time of enlightenment under the Bodhi tree, when he summoned the earth goddess Sthavara, to bear witness to his attainment of enlightenment. <!-- image --> Shakyamuni Buddha is commonly represented upon his enlightenment throne with his right hand touching the earth and his left hand resting upon his lap in the gesture of meditation. This symbolises his method or skillful means in overcoming Mara (right hand), through the perfect wisdom of his deep meditation on emptiness (left hand).

explanation: Statement 1 is not correct: A Hindu joint family consists of lineal descendants of a common ancestor. In other words, a male head and his descendants, including their wives and unmarried daughters. A coparcenary is a smaller unit of the family that jointly owns the property. The English term itself is borrowed from common law, but the concept is found in Hindu law . There are two main schools of law followed by Hindus -Mitakshara and Dayabhaga . <!-- image --> While Mitakshara School is followed in most parts of India, Dayabhaga School is confined to Bengal. Certain areas in South India are governed by Marumakkatayam, Aliyasantana, and Nambudiri systems of law. Castes are not specified in these laws. Statement 2 is correct: In the Mitakshara school, which prevails in most parts of India, a male's right to be a coparcener is by birth . In the Mitakshara system, the sons can claim the right to the property during the lifetime of the father. In the case of the Dayabhaga school of inheritance, the property is inherited by the successors (coparceners) only when the holder of the property is dead . Statement 3 is not correct: Both laws deal with the matters related to the property held by both male and female members of a family. Generally, it is seen that Mitakshara is biased against women & gave them very less right to inherit property. Although Dayabhaga is also biased, it gives more rights to women to inherit property compared to Mitakshara.

During the historical period, India had trade and cultural contacts with Egypt, Rome, Greeks, Arabs, China, and almost all Southeast Asian countries. through these ports. The ports on the west coast were Barygaya, Suppara, Calliena, Semylla, Mandagore, Palaepatme, Malizigara, Aurranobbas, Byzantine, Naura, Tyndis, Muziris and Nelcynda and the ports on the east coast were Tamralipti, Charitrapur, Paluru, Dantapur, Kalingapatnam, Pithunda, Sopatma, Ghantasala, Poduca, Puhar, Korkai, and Camara. In the Andhra region, the ports were Kadura and Ghantasala, Kaveripattanam (Puhar), and Tondail. These were the ports of the Pandya region. The ports of Kottayam and Muziris were on the Malabar coast. There was a great maritime trade between India and Southeast Asia and China.

text: With reference to the history of India, the terms 'kulyavapa' and 'dronavapa' denote (2020) -
explanation: Option (a) is correct: Gupta Economy: The agricultural crops constituted the main resources which the society produced and a major part of the revenue of the state came from agriculture. There are various types of land mentioned in the inscriptions. Land under cultivation was usually called Kshetra, Khila was the uncultivable land, Aprahata was the jungle or forest land, Gopata Sarah was the pastureland and Vasti was the habitable land. Different land measures were known in different regions such as Nivartana, Kulyavapa, and Dronavapa. In the inscriptions of Bengal, terms like Kulyavapa and Dronavapa have been used. It is not possible to classify the regions precisely according to the crops grown, but all the major categories of crops - cereals like barley, wheat, and paddy, different varieties of pulses, grams, and vegetables as well as cash crops like cotton and sugarcane - were known long before the Gupta period and continued to be cultivated.

explanation: The correct answer is (d) Both (a) and (b) are convincing explanations in this context. The maritime history of Indian shipbuilding begins right from the time of the Harappan Civilization. As compared to other countries, India had better ship-building technology in ancient and medieval times. It was during the Medieval period that a number of Indian Vessels were constructed purely for waging war at sea. During the days of the composition of Yuktikalpataru (around ninth century CE), it appears that shipbuilding was highly advanced. Hence option 1 is correct. Yuktikalpataru written by King Bhoja. The rules of southern India always patronized traders, brahmin priests and Buddhist monks in this context. Kanishka patronized Buddhist monks, Kushans patronized traders, Cholas patronized brahmin priests. Hence statement 2 is correct. Indians had Knowledge of Monsoon winds since the Gupta period. Monsoon winds across the Bay of Bengal facilitated sea voyages, but this was not the main reason that India maintained its early cultural contacts and trade links with Southeast Asia across the Bay of Bengal. He belonged to a Rajput clan. The Gurjara-Pratihara dynasty ruled much of Northern India from the mid-8th to the 11th century. The greatest ruler of the Pratihara dynasty was Mihira Bhoja (836-885 CE). He recovered Kannauj (Kanyakubja) by 836 A.D, and it remained the capital of the Pratiharas for almost a century. explanation: Option (d) is correct: 'Kalyana Mandapams' was a notable feature in the temple construction in the kingdom of Vijayanagara. The Vijayanagara Empire was founded by Harihara and Bukka in AD 1336 and made Hastinavati (Hampi) as the capital city. The temple-building activity of the Vijayanagar rulers produced a new style, called the Vijayanagar Style. The Vitthala Temple is one of the greatest monuments exemplifying the Vijayanagar Style (often characterised as Dravida Style) which dates from the 16th Century. It has several structures inside a rectangular court, one of which is the Kalyana Mandapa with elaborately carved pillars. Kalyana Mandapa is an open pavilion, which was used for ceremonies involving the symbolic marriage of the temple's divinity to his consort. ## Additional Information: They ruled over Andhra, Karnataka, Tamil Nadu, and parts of Kerala in southern India. text: In the context of cultural history of India, a pose in dance and dramatics called 'Tribhanga' has been a favourite of Indian artists from ancient times till today. Which one of the following statements best describes this pose? (2013) <!-- image --> <!-- image --> -
options: One leg is bent, and the body is slightly but oppositely curved at waist and neck -
Facial expressions, hand gestures and make-up are combined to symbolise certain epic or historic characters -
Movements of body, face and hands are used to express oneself or to tell a story -
A little smile, slightly curved waist and certain hand gestures are emphasised to express the feelings of love or eroticism
explanation: Option (a) is correct: Tribhanga is a (tri-bent pose) standing body position or stance used in the traditional Indian sculpture, art, and Indian classical dance forms like the Odissi. As, compared with the Contrapposto pose Tribhanga, meaning three parts, consists of three bends in the body; at the neck, waist, knee, hence the body is oppositely curved at waist and neck which gives it a gentle 'S' shape and is considered the most graceful and the sensual of the Odissi positions. It is closely associated with the Hindu deity, Krishna, who is often portrayed in the posture.

Answer: (d) Option (d) is correct: The Kishangarh province in Rajasthan is famous for its Bani Thani paintings. It is a style with highly exaggerated features like long necks, large, almond shaped eyes, and long fingers. This style of painting essentially depicts Radha and Krishna as divine lovers, and beautifully portrays their mystical love. Kishangarh miniature painting reached a peak in the eighteenth century, during the rule of Raja Sawant Singh, who fell in love with a slave girl, Bani Thani and commanded his artists to portray himself and her as Krishna and Radha. Other themes of Bani Thani paintings include portraits, court scenes, dancing, hunting, music parties, nauka vihar (lovers travelling in a boat), Krishna Lila, Bhagavata Purana and various festivals like Holi, Diwali, Durga puja, and Dussehra.

In Ajanta caves, the walls were originally covered in paintings, but today there are only nine surviving images present, Bodhisattva Padmapani being the most famous one. explanation: Pair 1 is correctly matched: The word Parivrajaka means 'roaming ascetic' or a wandering religious mendicant. Thus, Parivrajaka can be represented as Renunciant and Wanderer. Although this term occurs in the early Brahmanic tradition of the Upani sÃ£ hads, it is also applicable to Buddhist and Jain monks, as well as to Hindu sannyasins. The PƒÅli equivalent is paribbajaka. <!-- image --> Pair 2 is not correctly matched: The Shramana group, consisting of Buddhism, Jainism and various 'heterodox' sects, is a well-established group. Shramanas did not regard the Brahmans or a priest as being of the highest status. The sramanas included a variety of ascetics, as well as the monks and lay followers of various sects - Buddhist, Jaina, Ajivika and others. Pair 3 is correctly matched: Monks renounced social obligations to take on an alternative life when they joined the Buddhism Order. They lived as equal members of the Order, denying the caste distinctions. They lived in monasteries near villages and towns so that they could draw on the support of the lay community, namely those who were Buddhists or Jainas but were not initiated into renunciatory groups. Lay followers were referred to as upasaka and upasika. Elimination Technique : Sramana was an ancient Indian religious movement which rejected Vedic Hindu ritualism and the authority of the Brahmins-the traditional priests of the Hindu religion. Pair 2 is not correctly matched. Thus, Option (b) is correct.

text: Which one of the following pairs does not form part of the six systems of Indian Philosophy? (2014) -
explanation: The Six Systems of Indian Philosophy are: - y Nyaya: The Nyaya school was founded by sage Gautama. Sixteen major topics were discussed in this system, the most important of which is pramana, the source of valid knowledge. Nyaya is a school of logic, and all other schools of Indian philosophy use the Nyaya system of logic, in whole or in part, as a foundation for philosophical reasoning and debate. - y Vaisheshika: Kannada is the founder of this school, which is associated with the Nyaya system. This school discusses seven unacademy.com | Download the Unacademy app Give your feedback here: Link major topics: substance, quality, action, generality, uniqueness, inherence and nonexistence. - y Sankhya: Kapila is traditionally cited as the founder of this school, although his Samkhya Sutras have been lost. The Sankhya-karika of Isvara krsna, the oldest text on this philosophy, cites the names of Kapila, Asuri and Pancasikha as previous teachers at this school. It is considered to be the oldest of the philosophical systems. Sankhya is a dualistic philosophy that believes in the coexistent and interdependent realities, conscious Purusha and unconscious Prakrti. Sankhya philosophy explains the dynamics of the body and nature of mind. - y Yoga: Yoga and Sankhya are allied systems. Although Yoga philosophy was known even in the Vedic and pre-Vedic periods, it was not formally systematised until it was codified by Patanjali in about 200 BC. - y Mimamsa: Jamini was the founder of this system that accepts the Veda as the final authority on all questions. It provides a comprehensive method for interpreting and understanding the underlying meaning of the Veda. It lays great emphasis on rituals, worship and ethical conduct and provides a systematic lifestyle and direction - y Vedanta: It was taught and practised by the sages of the Vedas and Upanishads and was handed over through a long line of sages. The major schools of Vedanta are Advaita (non-dualistic), Dvaita (dualistic), Dvaitadvaita (both dualistic and non-dualistic), Visistadvaita (qualified nondualism) and Visuddhadvaita (pure non-dualism). Option (c) is correct: Lokayata and Kapalika do not form part of the six systems of Indian Philosophy. The Kapalika tradition was a nonpuranic, tantric form of Shaivism in India. The term Lokayata and Carvaka have historically been used to denote the philosophical school of Indian Materialism. Lokayata means the philosophy of the people.

The homes at Burzahom were pits dug below ground level using stone tools. The sides of the pits were plastered with mud. The pits were usually round or oval, narrow at the top and wide at the base. It is a Neolithic Site. With this, India brings to light transitions in human habitation patterns from Neolithic Period to the Megalithic period to the Early Historic period. From the transition in architecture to the development of toolmaking techniques to the introduction and diffusion of lentils in north-western India, the site of Burzahom is a unique, comprehensive storyteller of life between 3000 BCE to 1000 BCE. text: Muhammad-bin-Tughlaq temporarily lost portions of north-west of his kingdom to Mongols. Which of the statements given above is/are correct? -
explanation: Statement 1 is correct: When Iltutmish ascended the throne, he found himself surrounded by many problems. Other commanders of Muhammad Ghori rose in defiance again. The chief of Jalor and Ranthambore joined Gwalior and Kalinjar in declaring their independence. Apart from this, the rising power of Mongols under Chengiz Khan threatened the NorthWest Frontier of the Sultanate. In AD 1220, when Chenghiz Khan destroyed the Khwarezm empire , Iltutmish realised the political necessity of avoiding a confrontation with the Mongols . Thus, when Jalaluddin Mangbarani, the son of the Shah of Khwarizm, <!-- image --> while escaping from the Mongols, sought shelter at Iltutmish's court, Iltutmish turned him away. He thus saved the Sultanate from destruction by the Mongols. Statement 2 is not correct: Muhammad bin Tughluq reigned from 1324 to 1351. Taimur occupied Multan and crossed the river in 1398. Statement 3 is not correct: Vasco da Gama reached the coast of Kozhikode (Calicut), Kerala, in 1498. During this time, Narasimha Raya II was the ruler of the Vijayanagara Empire. He was the third and last ruler of the Saluva dynasty. Deva Raya II died in 1446.
subject: history_ancient

text: Banjaras during the medieval period of Indian history were (2016) -
explanation: Option (d) is correct: Banjaras during the medieval period of Indian history were generally traders. Banjaras played a role in Alaudin khilji 's market reforms. The Banjara are a community of nomadic people with their origins in Rajasthan. They were the trading groups that moved from one place to another in buying and selling goods. Their population is divided into Kashmir, Bengal, Gujarat, and Karnataka, and are now found all over India. They are also called Lamans, Lambadi, Lambhani, Lambani, and Gormati. ## Elimination Technique: Option (a), (b) and (c) can be easily eliminated, as it is not related to warriors, agricultures and weavers.
subject: history_ancient

text: With reference to the economic history of medieval India, the term 'Araghatta' refers to (2016) -
options: bonded labor unacademy.com | Download the Unacademy app Give your feedback here: Link <!-- image --> <!-- image --> -
land grants made to military officers -
waterwheel used in the irrigation of land -
explanation: Option (c) is correct: The term 'Araghatta' comes from the combination of the words 'ara' meaning spoke and 'ghatta' meaning pot. It is a Persian wheel used in irrigation in medieval India. It is a mechanical device used to lift water. It uses animal power to lift water from sources, especially from open wells. The animals used here are cattle, bullocks, etc. With its use also in Iran, then Persia, and perhaps its discovery there, it came to be called the Persian wheel.
subject: history_ancient

text: Land assignments to Jagirdars were hereditary and the revenue rights of Zamindars were not hereditary. Select the correct answer using the code given below: -
explanation: Option (a) is correct: During the Mughal time, there were large provinces called Suba . Every Suba was divided into several Sarkars or districts . Each Sarkar was divided into smaller units called Parganas. So, the correct order is Paragana - Sarkar - Suba. The sarkars, into which each suba was divided , often overlapped with the jurisdiction of faujdars (commandants), who were deployed with contingents of heavy cavalry and musketeers in districts. The local administration was looked after at the level of the pargana (sub-district) by three semi-hereditary officers, the qanungo (keeper of revenue records), the chaudhuri (in charge of revenue collection), and the qazi.
subject: history_ancient

text: It was during the region of Deva Raya II of the Vijayanagara Empire that Vasco da Gama reached the coast of Kerala. Which of the statements given above is / are correct? -
explanation: Option (c) is correct: Akbar's reign saw illustrations of manuscripts, the prominent being Razmnama which is the Persian translation of Mahabharata. It was during Jahangir's reign that manuscripts became less important and there was more focus on individual portraits. Under Jahangir, paintings acquired greater charm, refinement, and dignity. Jahangir had a great fascination for nature and took pleasure in the portraiture of birds, animals, and flowers.

text: Private owners of workshops paid an industry tax. Which of the statements given above is/are correct? -
options: 2 only unacademy.com | Download the Unacademy app Give your feedback here: Link <!-- image --> -
explanation: Option (b) is correct: During the Vijaynagar Empire, Fanams were coins which were used in day-to-day life. Fanam was usually a small fraction of the main currency (Pagoda or Varaha). The Travancore Fanam was a form of money issued by the State of Travancore in South India, which is today mostly a part of Kerala. Fanams (sometimes spelled Fanoms) and Chuckrams (or Chakrams) were renowned to be among the world's tiniest coins. Fanam appears to be an Anglo-Germanic sound shift from Panam, which in Dravidian languages denotes money. The Fanam and Chuckram coins were the standard units of currency in medieval Travancore, and they appear to have been widely utilised for trade in the South Indian region. In Kerala's original language, Malayalam, the words Fanam and Panam literally mean money and are still used as synonyms for riches.

text: Bhoja Rashtrakuta How many pairs given above are correctly matched? -
explanation: Statement 1 not is correct: Nizamat of Arcot was established by Mughal Emperor Aurangzeb and was the legal dependency of the Nizam of Hyderabad; it did not emerge from the Hyderabad state. Statement 2 is correct: Mysore was transformed from a viceroyalty of the Vijayanagara Empire into an autonomous state by the Wodeyar dynasty. The Mysore Kingdom emerged out of Vijayanagara Empire. Statement 3 is not correct: The states of Rohilkhand and the kingdom of the Bangash Pathans were a fallout of the Afghan migration into India. Large-scale immigration of Afghans into India took place in the mid-18th century because of political and economic turmoil in Afghanistan. Ali Muhammad Khan took advantage of the collapse of authority in North India following Nadir Shah's invasion to set up a petty kingdom, Rohilkhand. This was the area of the Himalayan foothills between Kumaon in the north and the Ganga in the south. ## Elimination Technique: Here statement 3 is not correct, then you can easily eliminate (c) and (d) options. It was Ali Muhammad Khan not Ahmad Shah Durrani. ## 5 . Answer: (b) Option (b) is correct: Jean-Baptiste Tavernier (1605 -89) was one of the most renowned travellers of 17th-century Europe. The son of a French Protestant who had fled Antwerp to unacademy.com | Download the Unacademy app Give your feedback here: Link <!-- image --> <!-- image --> escape religious persecution, Tavernier was a jewel merchant who between 1632 and 1668 made six voyages to the East. The countries he visited (most more than once) included present-day Cyprus, Malta, Turkey, Syria, Iraq, Iran, Afghanistan, Pakistan, India, Sri Lanka, and Indonesia. While on his travels to India he discovered and discussed diamonds and diamond mines of India extensively.

text: Which one of the following was a very important seaport in the Kakatiya kingdom? (2017) -
explanation: Option (b) is correct: The Kakatiya dynasty was a South Indian dynasty, and the capital of the Kakatiya dynasty was Orugallu which is known as Warangal. Motupalli was an important seaport in the kingdom of Ganpati (an important Kakatiya ruler), frequented by foreign merchants. Italian traveler Marco Polo who had visited the port in 1287 AD, had given a vivid account on the flourishing trade activities at the port during the reign of Kakatiya queen Rudrama Devi. Plans are afoot for the integrated development of Motupalli, a historic port in Chinnaganjam mandal of the Prakasam district. The tourism potential of the village, where the bronze idols of Lord Nataraja, his consort Parvati, their son Ganesha and Alwars, the Bhakti movement saints dating back to the 12th century, were found in the 1970s, has remained hitherto untapped.
subject: history_ancient

text: Who of the following founded a new city on the south bank of a tributary to river Krishna and undertook to rule his new kingdom as the agent of a deity to whom all the land south of the river Krishna was supposed to belong? (2015) -
explanation: Option (c) is correct: Vijayanagara or 'city of victory', was the name of both a city and an empire. Harihara I and Bukka founded the Vijayanagar Empire in the fourteenth century. It stretched from the river Krishna in the north to the extreme south of the Peninsula (KrishnaTungabhadra doab). - y Harihara I established control over the valley of the Tungabhadra River (a tributary of Krishna). Then gradually he expanded his control to certain regions of Konkan and Malabar Coast. - y By that time Hoysalas had lost its last ruler Veera Ballala III, who died fighting the Sultan of Madurai, and the vacuum created facilitated Harihara I to emerge as a sovereign power. The entire Hoysala territories came under his rule directly.
